reviewText:
We have eaten both dinner and Sunday brunch at this Rocky Mountain bistro on multiple occasions and feel that we can comfortable reviewing this restaurant.  Here is a quick summary:
1.  The restaurant is hidden in a courtyard off Larimer Street, which has some charm.  It is immediately across the street from Rioja, its sister restaurant.  
2.  If you are driving you can pull up to Rioja for valet parking ($10 plus tip) and just walk across the street which is very convenient.
3.  The restaurant is owned by Chef Jennifer Jasinski- winner of the 2013 James Beard  Best Chef Southwest Award and a semi-finalist for the 216 James Beard Best Chef Award.
4.  The restaurant has great ambiance in the bar, main dining area and the patio.  As you would find in a Parisian bistro, the tables are closely packed together.
5.  The dress code, like many Denver area restaurants, is relaxed with most diners being casual (three of our four diners wore jeans) to business casual with scattered diners being smartly dressed.
5.  While the restaurant has Parisian influences, it is not a classic Parisian menu and many "foodie purists" expecting an exact replica of Parisian food will be disappointed.  This is reflected in a number of reviews where diners are disappointed that the menu does not reflect their dining experience in Paris.
6.  The menu is divided into Hors D'Oeuvres that includes a daily cheese board, Primary Plates, Steak Frites, Salads, Small Plates and Desserts.  On this evening our party had the onion soup (excellent), Crepe Vendome (excellent), duck confit (very good), scallops (very good), steak frites (excellent) and creme brulee (excellent).  For those that have not tried the unusual take on their French fries, I would strongly recommend them- in my opinion they are excellent.
7.  Service was excellent and friendly- certainly better than anything that we experienced in three trips to Paris (I also lived there for four years).
8.  While I highly recommend this restaurant, I have two caveats that you need to take into account before dining here.  First as other reviews have reported, the portions are not large- do not expect a giant slab of beef or lamb as most Americans are used to.  However, many will find the portions adequate if you have an appetizer or salad course, main course and a dessert.  Second, in my opinion some of the items are slightly oversalted.  This is of course a matter of opinion and some will find the salt levels suited to their taste.
reviewTitle: French food with Rocky Mountain influences

reviewText: What a lovely, lovely restaurant, nestled in a gorgeous alleyway off the main thoroughfare of Larimer Square.  When eating at a French restaurant, why did I order steak?  I could not resist the Steak au Poivre and found it a bit too peppery, as did a companion who ordered the same meal.  The ladies ordered more French cuisine and were delighted with their choices.  I did have an accompanimant of the Frites, and they were delicious, as advertised, and would eat here again just for another try.

My husband and I enjoyed a lovely dinner at this intimate, nearly Parisian bistro. Ambience, food and service were all at the same high level. The moules, as well as the beet and date salad were very fine starters, the former in a light, not too garlicky broth while the latter was nicely proportioned and perfectly dressed. The duck confit was just as it should be -- falling off the bone tender and well seasoned. Its accompaniments, which included turnips three ways, were welcome pairings. The steak frites (au poivre in our case) was a simple affair, just as it should be, and done to a turn.  The potatoes were crisp, salty and plentifull. The wine, recommended by our server, was an excellent choice (though I can't recall what it was). All in all, Bistro Vendome is a keeper.

I was invited to Bistro Vendome on a first date and it made a wonderful first impression!  It is a quaint little bistro that could very well have been on the streets of Paris.  In addition to the lovely romantic ambiance, I was thoroughly impressed with the food and service.  We tried the escargot and halibut found them both to be delicious and delectable!
reviewTitle: A slice of Paris in Denver!

reviewText:
Recently took friends from London and SF here while they were visiting. The pluses: Great steak frites, delicious creme brûlée and other desserts. Reasonable wine list. Nice ambience with the lights and shops on Larimer street. The minuses: $28+ for one lamb chop. That made quite an impression on our guests, especially in comparison to the lower priced steak frites. As one put it, in the most English sort of way, they didn't realize there were so many dieting supermodels dining in Denver these days. 

Second minus: waitress was a stickler for glass of wine pricing at end of happy hour while we were waiting for our table, and shortly thereafter after we had been seated and prices were much higher. Right call would have been to suggest ordering a bottle at the happy hour price. But she stayed silent about that.  Our guests felt like they had been hustled, which detracted from their opinion of Vendome. Staff at world class restaurants don't behave this way.

Bottom line: This is a local Denver restaurant we had hoped would impress our guests from some of the worlds' top restaurant cities. On balance, it sadly fell short. Expensive and in too many ways, disappointing. We won't make this mistake again.

reviewText: This is a fun sports bar with great service. I eat there regularly and have never had any issues with the food or the service. They have daily and happy hour specials. The atmosphere is laid back. A great place to watch the game and grab a beer.

We had lunch at the Bricks at the suggestion of Trip Advisor and we were not disappointed.
We ordered the Club Sandwhich and the Reuben.  The beer was cold the tea was fresh and the service was good.  

The owner (Mike) was the bartender and was very friendly.

This is a good stopping place in a town you might think has nothing to offer. We just had sandwiches but they were both well prepared and the food came quickly.

Neither my friend, my mother-in-law or I really care for the food here, & the service is something to be reckoned with. But my hubs ate there with a friend, and said it was "Better", catfish was good!

The food was standard brew pub fare but both of our entries (the fajitas and the grilled salmon) were very well prepared and the salad bar was a nice change of pace.  The server was extremely friendly and the owner stopped by our table to say hello.  After a long day's drive, it was fun to have have a beer, munch on the basket of peanuts (shells go on the floor) and have a nice leisurely dinner.   There were lots of people there, playing pool and watching sports on the big screen.  There's a separate room for families if you don't want the kids hanging out in the room with the bar.

reviewText: The Bricks is a great place to eat and have a cold beer.  The service is excellent and so is the atmosphere and food. The owners are there everyday helping wait tables, serve drinks and visit with the customers. We go to the Bricks frequently and have always had a very positive experience. I highly recommend the Pub on the Bricks!

I have never eaten in the old restaurant The Bricks, and in fact I frequent The Pub on the Bricks almost three times a month now. I do NOT live in town (in face I live half an hour away) and this place has been a little jewel in Guymon in my opinion. I just about always get the same things (The St. Louis Ribs) and have loved everything I've had there - except for the mashed potatoes. Service for the most part is excellent and I haven't really had much of a complaint in the 20 or so times that I have been there with different friends. I would recommend this to a friend, in face just about anytime we go to Guymon for a meal, I do recommend it.

The Bricks has a restaurant area in the front and a bar area in the back.  I got the impression it was an old livery stable or similar type building converted into a restaurant so it really has a cool atmosphere.  The hostess was excellent and the wait staff good but the food was only so-so.  We were mostly dissappointed in the mashed potatoes and the Friday night special, calf fries.  They were small with a lot of breading.  To the restaurant's credit, it did appear to be a popular place for the locals and many of the other plates that passed by us smelled delicious and had very large servings.  We might have had a different opinion had we ordered anything other than fried foods.

Where else can you get a different $5 meal five days a week? The handy downtown location gives the restaurant an old town feeling with convenience to the court house and many businesses. The south side of the restaurant is your regular restaurant look while the north side bar area has a great painted mural and fun, sport themed atmosphere. We find the servers very attentive and Michael Davis, the manager, goes out of his way to make everyone comfortable. The menu varies from hamburgers, Tex-Mex and more. The $5 specials show a lot of variety and sometimes they offer new dishes not on the menu. I particullarly like the hambugers and handcut french fries! It is a great place to meet friends and to hold meetings of any kind. They are open on Sunday too!
Great service, great food and great atmosphere, do you need anything else when out of town for dinner....

Concerning the previous person who wrote such a scathing review, allow me to say this:  I am a broadcast professional who was recruited to fix a local radio station and arrived here last Monday night.  On Wednesday my new general manager took me to a lunch meeting here and it a nutshell, it was EXCEPTIONAL!!  Extremely attentive server, fast turnaround on the orders and the food was absolutely delicious.  So I decided to check out the bar last weekend.  Again in a nutshell EXCEPTIONAL!  Fast knowledgeable bartenders, very reasonable drink prices, tons of people in the house and a very festive atmosphere all around.  TO EVERYONE Traveling through Guymon, I highly recommend this fine establishment!

The bill was slightly over $100 for four adults and that did not include alcoholic beverages which is an expensive dinner for Guymon.  Do NOT waste your money on this place - it is so NOT worth it. Overall, a "wannabe" resturant that does NOT have the food or service to justify such expensive meals.
